snippet: As the prime minister struggles to put down an insurgency led by Qaeda-affiliated militants, he has taken to paying tribal militias to fight as proxies, as the Americans did in 2007.
abstract: Iraqi Prime Min Nuri Kamal al-Maliki, in attempt to put down insurgency led by Al Qaeda-affiliated militants, has embraced same strategy Americans used in 2007, paying and arming local Sunni tribal fighters to fight as proxies; his efforts to recruit Sunni fighters have been hampered by local mistrust of the government and fear of Qaeda revenge.

byline.original: By TIM ARANGO and KAREEM FAHIM
byline.contributor: Yasir Ghazi and Duraid Adnan contributed reporting from Baghdad, and an employee of The New York Times from Anbar Province.

lead_paragraph: As the prime minister struggles to put down an insurgency led by Qaeda-affiliated militants, he has taken to paying tribal militias to fight as proxies, as the Americans did in 2007.

headline.main: Iraq Again Uses Sunni Tribesmen in Militant War
headline.print_headline: Iraq Again Uses Sunni Tribesmen in Militant War
